description: Bangkok- Cambodian authorities should urgently investigate the abduction in broad daylight of a Thai pro-democracy activist in the capital Phnom Penh, Human Rights Watch said on Friday. He fled to Cambodia after Thailand's military seized power in a coup in May 2014 and continued to be politically active on social media. Thai police issued an arrest warrant...
text:
Bangkok (dpa) - Cambodian authorities should urgently investigate the
abduction in broad daylight of a Thai pro-democracy activist in the capital
Phnom Penh, Human Rights Watch said on Friday.

The New York-based rights group said Wanchalearm Satsaksit was abducted at
around 6 pm on Thursday by a group of armed men who took him away in a black
car as he walked to buy food in front of his apartment, according to witnesses
and apartment security cameras.

Thai police spokesman Colonel Krissana Pattanacharoen said Thai authorities do
not have information on the abduction as it took place outside the country.

South-East Asian countries have been repeatedly accused of turning a blind eye
to the apprehension of exiled activists and even sending them back home under
no legal framework.

Krissana said Thai police have not coordinated with Cambodian authorities.

Wanchalerm is affiliated with Thailand's pro-democracy "red shirt" movement
which opposes the country's traditional establishment and the military's
dominance in politics.

He fled to Cambodia after Thailand's military seized power in a coup in May
2014 and continued to be politically active on social media.

Thai police issued an arrest warrant for Wanchalerm in June 2018 for running
the Facebook page which roughly translates "I will surely get 100 million baht
from Thaksin," a satirical reference to former prime minister Thaksin
Shinawatra.

Thaksin, a billionaire telecommunications tycoon, was ousted as prime minister
in a 2006 military coup and is often accused by his political enemies of
buying support.

# Notebook

title: Thai activist abducted by armed men in Cambodia, rights group says
html:
Bangkok (dpa) - Cambodian authorities should urgently investigate the abduction in broad daylight of a Thai pro-democracy activist in the capital Phnom Penh, Human Rights Watch said on Friday.

The New York-based rights group said Wanchalearm Satsaksit was abducted at around 6 pm on Thursday by a group of armed men who took him away in a black car as he walked to buy food in front of his apartment, according to witnesses and apartment security cameras.

Thai police spokesman Colonel Krissana Pattanacharoen said Thai authorities do not have information on the abduction as it took place outside the country.

South-East Asian countries have been repeatedly accused of turning a blind eye to the apprehension of exiled activists and even sending them back home under no legal framework.

Krissana said Thai police have not coordinated with Cambodian authorities.

Wanchalerm is affiliated with Thailand's pro-democracy "red shirt" movement which opposes the country's traditional establishment and the military's dominance in politics.

He fled to Cambodia after Thailand's military seized power in a coup in May 2014 and continued to be politically active on social media.

Thai police issued an arrest warrant for Wanchalerm in June 2018 for running the Facebook page which roughly translates "I will surely get 100 million baht from Thaksin," a satirical reference to former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra.

Thaksin, a billionaire telecommunications tycoon, was ousted as prime minister in a 2006 military coup and is often accused by his political enemies of buying support.

# Notebook
